title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child, subject to income limitations. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses not exceeding $5,000 per child, with income limitations reducing the credit based on adjusted gross income. No double benefit allowed. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses not exceeding $5,000 per child, with income limitations reducing the credit based on adjusted gross income. No double benefit allowed for expenses covered by other provisions or received from government programs. The Adoption Assistance Act allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses, excluding funds received from government programs. Qualified expenses include adoption fees, court costs, and attorney fees directly related to the legal adoption of a child by the taxpayer. The Adoption Assistance Act allows a credit for qualified adoption expenses, which are directly related to the legal adoption of a child by the taxpayer and not incurred in violation of any laws. Expenses for the adoption of a spouse's child are not eligible for this credit. The term 'qualified adoption expenses' does not include expenses for adopting a child who is the spouse's child. Married couples must file joint returns for this section. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. Title II of the document focuses on Adoption Assistance for Federal Employees, specifically addressing reimbursement for adoption expenses. The effective date for the amendments mentioned is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Reimbursement is provided after the adoption becomes final. Reimbursement for adoption expenses is available to employees if the adoption becomes final, the child is under 18 years old and unmarried, and the appropriate application is filed. Reimbursement for adoption expenses under this section is payable if similar benefits from other programs have not covered the full amount, with a maximum limit of $2,000 per child. If both adopting parents are eligible employees, each parent can receive reimbursement. The reimbursement for adoption expenses under this section is limited to $2,000 per child. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments made by an employer for qualified adoption expenses. The text chunk defines terms related to adoption assistance benefits, including employer, employee, military adoption assistance benefits, and qualified adoption expenses. The text chunk specifies that qualified adoption expenses include adoption fees, court costs, attorney fees, and other related expenses for the legal adoption of an eligible child by the taxpayer. The text chunk defines eligible child as an individual under 18 or incapable of self-care for adoption purposes, not violating any laws.
